subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... I get the feeling that we only need to add one feature to JUnit to have it match TestNG in this regard: labeling tests as SetUp failed when setUp()
messageBody:
Cedric Beust wrote:
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
>
> > I see setUp just as a programmatical way to remove
> > duplication, not as a separate entity.
>
> You can see it any way you want, I am just saying that it's not very useful
> to read "101 FAILURES" as opposed to "1 FAILURE, 100 SKIPS".
>
> And as I was saying earlier, you are probably so used to JUnit that when you
> read "101 FAILURES", you just *know* that it's not true that 101 tests
> failed. You know that only one of them failed (maybe a setUp or another
> test) and all the other ones are failing in cascade.
>
> And you also know that you probably only need to fix *1* test to come back
> to "101 SUCCESSES".
>
> Now, wouldn't it be nice if the testing framework told you exactly *which*
> test you should look at first?

I get the feeling that we only need to add one feature to JUnit to have
it match TestNG in this regard: labeling tests as "SetUp failed" when
setUp() throws an exception. Right now, they are usually reported as
errors, and so are lumped in with other unexpected exceptions.
